Award.AwardTitle: NSF GK-12 Graduate STEM Fellows in K-12 Education GLACIER-Global Change Initiative-Education & Research

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Global-scale environmental changes are critical to our survival as they may affect the capacity of the Earth to sustain life. From the perspective of education and research, the topic of global change presents a rich domain of inquiry, exploration, and discovery at all grade levels. GLACIER's primary goal is to provide graduate fellows a strong interdisciplinary perspective on global change research by training them to observe and analyze both physical and anthropogenic processes and their consequences at a variety of spatial and temporal scales. GLACIER fellows will also have the opportunity to enhance their teaching skills and learn how to translate their research into exciting and dynamic STEM classroom lessons in grades 5- 8. GLACIER will also train teachers to use geospatial technologies (such as remote sensing, Global Positioning Systems (GPS), and Geographical Information Systems (GIS)); learn about methods and field work used to study global change, create sustainable curricula for grades 5-8 based on an inter-disciplinary approach, and cultivate new ways of engaging their students to think about environmental problems.

Broader Impacts: GLACIER will help educate a citizenry that can make informed decisions about the environment, and to train future generation of scientists with a multi-disciplinary perspective and strong analytical skills. Finally, systematic evaluation criteria will provide feedback regarding the value of our multi-disciplinary focus. GLACIER will strengthen the ties between Boston University and two partner school districts of Cambridge and Brookline, as well as enhance existing links to local museums, zoo, aquarium, and other field sites.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Boston University's NSF GK12 program called Global Change Initiative Education and Research (GLACIER) was designed to connect graduate fellows in the science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) disciplines with teachers in Grades 5-8 classrooms in the Boston area. Its focus was to enhance the science curricula related to global change in the following five thematic areas: biosphere, atmosphere, hydrosphere, energy, and data and measurement. The program spanned seven years, included 54 STEM fellows partnered with 45 teachers in 30 schools in Boston, Brookline, Newton, Cambridge, Somerville, Everett, and Quincy.  

Our program achieved the anticipated outcomes of the program including improved communication, teaching, collaboration, and team-building skills for the fellows achieved through partnerships with teachers, as well as experiences in Boston University’s summer training program and weekly seminar class; professional development opportunities for K–12 teachers via summer training program; enhanced learning for K–12 students on the topic of global change; and strengthened and sustained partnerships in STEM between Boston University and the local school districts. Our annual evaluation reports show that GLACIER fellows gained important mentoring and teaching skills, as well as an understanding of the needs of K–12 teachers and classrooms. Some fellows have reported that these skills have impacted their future teaching careers. Fellows have appreciated the connections to local community and the chance to teach in middle school classrooms. Their role as resident scientists at schools enhanced their confidence and motivated their participation in other events (e.g. science fairs). The curriculum developed by the fellows is posted on the GLACIER  website. Fellows worked closely with their teachers to prepare STEM curricula that fit with the school district’s STEM standards and hence can be used by other teachers in the same or other schools.

With respect to teachers, our project showed that teachers gained from the “partnership-building” summer workshops, learned new science concepts from their partner fellows during their in-classroom team teaching, and gained confidence in integrating inquiry-based lessons more frequently in their curriculum, as well as the use of new equipment and technology in their classrooms. The program involved 10-12 faculty at Boston University in various STEM disciplines. Faculty have visited middle school classrooms and have developed partnerships with the teachers via outreach programs in other NSF grants. These connections, as well as a curriculum that resulted from the program (posted on the website), and the fellows' improved understanding of STEM learning in schools and curricula development will sustain the program impacts for the next three to five years. Our NSF-funded GK–12 program has had a significant impact on all participants, including 54 graduate students, 50 classroom teachers, and around 5000 middle school students in the Boston area, and has created and strengthened university and K–12 partnerships.
